text: Wellesley’s rigorous and dynamic academic program allows each student to pursue a course of study that’s right for her.

Wellesley requires each student to acquire a broad knowledge of the basic fields of human inquiry, while also enabling her to follow her own particular interests in depth. Our core curriculum is strategically designed to deliver on Wellesley’s rigorous academic and educational goals.

In addition to the core curriculum, Wellesley offers an impressive variety of educational opportunities. A high percentage of our students participate in one or more of these choices, making them an important part of the overall Wellesley academic experience. These include:
—approximately half of our students study abroad at some point during their time at Wellesley.
Research opportunities—our students work closely with professors on meaningful, challenging projects.
—students can select a number of majors that combine academic disciplines, or choose interdepartmental majors.
—Wellesley supports a diverse variety of summer internships and community service projects around the world; many are eligible for financial support.

—students can enroll in cross-registration programs with Babson College, Brandeis University, MIT, and Olin College of Engineering, among other exchange programs with other colleges in the United States. Students can also apply to selective programs to earn a double degree with MIT or a combined five-year BA/MA in international economics and finance (BA/MAief) with Brandeis University.

A degree from Wellesley College demonstrates that a student has constructed a broad intellectual foundation, as well as pursued a passionate interest to admirable accomplishment. Perhaps that is why a Wellesley education is highly prized among graduate schools and employers alike.
Two out of three female U.S. Secretaries of State have been Wellesley grads.
Students present their work across academic disciplines in a community celebration of student achievement. Performances, readings, panels, and presentations fill an entire day each spring.
Interested in government? Learn about it firsthand in government offices, political and public interest groups, media, or research and cultural institutions. Housing and a stipend are provided.
